sen.j: 祖霊舎（それい しゃ・みたま や）とは、神道において祖先の霊を祭るための神棚である。
sen.e: Soreisha (or Mitamaya) is a household Shinto altar to enshrine ancestral souls in Shinto.
Soreisha (or Mitamaya) are household altars that are used in Shinto to enshrine ancestral spirits.

sen.j: 霊舎・霊屋・霊棚(たまだな)・霊床(たまとこ)・神道壇（しんとだん）などともいう。
sen.e: It is also called reisha, tamaya (a mausoleum), tamadana, tamatoko or shintodan.
They are also called reisha, tamaya, tamadana, tamatoko and shintodan.
sen.cmt: I have deleted "(a mausoleum)" as I don't think this is the sense that the word is being used in here—I don't think many homes have a mausoleum.
sen.e: They are also called reisha, tamaya, tamadana, tamatoko and shintodan.

sen.j: 神社本庁では霊舎としている。
sen.e: Jinja-Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) calls it reisha.
Jinja-Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) calls such altars reisha.
sen.cmt: It was great that the translator provided the English for Jinja-Honcho. This will be very helpful to the reader.
sen.e: Jinja-Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) calls such altars reisha.

sen.j: 神社の中にある祖先の霊を祀る施設は祖霊社と表記して区別する。
sen.e: Facilities to enshrine ancestral souls inside Shinto shrines are written as 祖霊社 (soreisha shrine), and distinguished from 祖霊舎 (soreisha).
sen.cmt: 漢字表記を訳文に使用しました。
sen.e: Facilities in Shinto shrines for enshrining the spirits of deceased ancestors are identified with a sign saying 祖霊社 (the reading for which is "soreisha", meaning ancestral shrine) rather than 祖霊舎 (the reading for which is also "soreisha", meaning ancestral altar).

Facilities in Shinto shrines for enshrining the spirits of deceased ancestors are identified with a sign saying 祖霊社 (the reading for which is "soreisha", meaning ancestral shrine) rather than 祖霊舎 (the reading for which is also "soreisha", meaning ancestral altar).

sen.j: 神道による祖先祭祀において、仏壇に代わる物として登場した。
sen.e: Soreisha was introduced as an alternative to Buddhist alters in religious services for ancestors in Shinto.
Soreisha were introduced as an alternative to Buddhist alters in conducting Shinto religious services for ancestors.
Soreisha were introduced as an alternative to Buddhist alters in conducting Shinto religious services for ancestors.

sen.j: 神棚よりも低い位置に祀るものだとされている。
sen.e: It should be placed below the household Shinto altar.
They are placed below a Kamidana (a household Shinto altar hung high on a wall in a cupboard or on shelf).
sen.cmt: The translator should try to make sure that the translation will make sense to a native speaker of English with little or no knowledge of Japanese/Japan. The way the original translation reads is that a Soreisha (meaning a household Shinto altar) should be placed below the household Shinto altar... I'm afraid this would make no sense to the reader.
sen.e: They are placed below a Kamidana (a household Shinto altar hung high on a wall in a cupboard or on shelf).

sen.j: 設置の向きや日々の供物や拝礼の作法は神棚と同じように行なうが、順番は神棚の後にする。
sen.e: The direction of installation and the manner for offering daily altarage and worshiping are the same as for household Shinto alters, but offering and worshiping should be done after household Shinto altars.

The direction of installation and the manner for making daily offers to the alter and worship are the same as for household Shinto alters, but offers and worship should be done after household Shinto altars.

sen.j: 仏教における仏壇に当たるものである。
sen.e: It corresponds to a Buddhist alter in Buddhism.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It corresponds to a Buddhist altar in Buddhism.

sen.j: 本来仏壇とは仏像を祭るためのものであるのに対して、祖霊舎は祖先の霊を家の守護神として祭る点に大きな違いがある。
sen.e: While Buddhist alters are originally for enshrining Buddha statues, soreisha enshrine ancestral spirits for being guardian deities for the houses, and this is the major difference between them.
